CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: Significant progress has been made in synthesis of conjugated polymers and their applications for optoelectronic device such as organic light - emitting diodes ( OLEDs ) , organic photovoltaic cells ( OPVs ) , and organic field - effect transistors ( OFETs ) since Heeger , MacDiarmid , and Shirakawa discovered conducting polymers in 1976.^1 As a result of the low - cost , light - weight , and flexibility advantages , optoelectronic devices based on conjugated polymers are a promising cost - effective alternative to inorganic materials - based microelectronics. Conjugated polymers can be classified as hole ( p - type ) or electron ( n - type ) transporting materials according to the type of orderly transferring charge carriers. Most of conjugated polymers are p - type semiconductors that have seen a dramatic rise in performance over the past decade while much less attention has been devoted to n - type semiconducting polymers that have lagged behind their p - type counterparts. 2 Organic n - type materials are essential for the fabrication of organic p-n junctions , OPVs , n-channel OFETs , OLEDs , and complementary logic circuits. 3 The n - type building blocks are the core components in n - type semiconducting polymers. Aromatic imides such as rylene diimides are one of the classical n - type building blocks and can exhibit relatively high electron affinities , high electron mobilities , and excellent chemical , thermal , and photochemical stabilities. 4 These materials are electron deficient due to the substitution of an aromatic core with one or two sets of π-accepting imide groups that are mutually conjugated. The widely used rylene diimides include perylene diimides ( PDIs , 1 ) and naphthalene diimides ( NDIs , 2 ) ( Figure 1 ). Zhan and co-workers reported the synthesis of the first soluble rylene-based fully conjugated polymer. 5 Top-gate OFETs based on this PDI- dithienothiophene copolymer exhibited a saturation electron mobility ( μ e ) of 6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 , current on / off ratio ( I on / I off ) of 10^4 , and a low threshold voltage ( V th ) of 7 V in air. 6 Moreover , all - polymer solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors exhibited power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as high as 1.5% ( AM1.5 , 100 mW cm^-2 ). 7-9 Facchetti et al. reported a conjugated copolymer of NDI and bithiophene ; 10 OFET devices based on this polymer fabricated in a top-gate , bottom - contact configuration with polymeric dielectrics exhibited μ e of 0.1-0.85 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 under ambient conditions with I on / I off > 10^5 . 11 The simplest aromatic imide system is phthalimide ( 3 ) and thiophene imide ( 4 ) ( Figure 1 ). A few literatures reported phthalimide - containing conjugated polymers such as poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s , 12 a polyaniline derivative , 13 and a polythiophene derivative.

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Let's identify the "Material Name" entities in the paragraph:

1. Conjugated polymers
 * Type: Polymers
 * Properties: Conducting, semiconducting
2. Organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs)
 * Type: Optoelectronic device
 * Properties: Emits light
3. Organic photovoltaic cells (OPVs)
 * Type: Optoelectronic device
 * Properties: Convert sunlight into electricity
4. Organic field-effect transistors (OFETs)
 * Type: Optoelectronic device
 * Properties: Controls the flow of current
5. Perylene diimides (PDIs)
 * Type: Aromatic imide
 * Properties: Electron-deficient, high electron affinity, high electron mobility, chemical stability
6. Naphthalene diimides (NDIs)
 * Type: Aromatic imide
 * Properties: Electron-deficient, high electron affinity, high electron mobility, chemical stability
7. Polythiophene derivative
 * Type: Polymer
 * Properties: Donor in solar cells
8. Bithiophene
 * Type: Polymer
 * Properties: Acceptor in solar cells
9. Phthalimide
 * Type: Aromatic imide
 * Properties: Containing conjugated polymers
10. Thiophene imide
 * Type: Aromatic imide
 * Properties: Containing conjugated polymers

Note: Some of these entities may have multiple names or synonyms, but I have listed them according to their most common names used in the paragraph.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

Of course! Here are the entities that clearly refer to "Material Name" in the paragraph:

1. Conjugated polymers
2. Perylene diimides (PDIs)
3. Naphthalene diimides (NDIs)
4. Polythiophene derivative
5. Bithiophene

These are the only entities in the paragraph that are directly related to the concept of "Material Name".

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Certainly! Here are the valid entities related to "Material Name" in the paragraph, presented in a Markdown table with one column "Material Name":

| Material Name |
| --- |
| Conjugated polymers |
| Perylene diimides (PDIs) |
| Naphthalene diimides (NDIs) |
| Polythiophene derivative |
| Bithiophene |

PN.content:
Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: Significant progress has been made in synthesis of conjugated polymers and their applications for optoelectronic device such as organic light - emitting diodes ( OLEDs ) , organic photovoltaic cells ( OPVs ) , and organic field - effect transistors ( OFETs ) since Heeger , MacDiarmid , and Shirakawa discovered conducting polymers in 1976.^1 As a result of the low - cost , light - weight , and flexibility advantages , optoelectronic devices based on conjugated polymers are a promising cost - effective alternative to inorganic materials - based microelectronics. Conjugated polymers can be classified as hole ( p - type ) or electron ( n - type ) transporting materials according to the type of orderly transferring charge carriers. Most of conjugated polymers are p - type semiconductors that have seen a dramatic rise in performance over the past decade while much less attention has been devoted to n - type semiconducting polymers that have lagged behind their p - type counterparts. 2 Organic n - type materials are essential for the fabrication of organic p-n junctions , OPVs , n-channel OFETs , OLEDs , and complementary logic circuits. 3 The n - type building blocks are the core components in n - type semiconducting polymers. Aromatic imides such as rylene diimides are one of the classical n - type building blocks and can exhibit relatively high electron affinities , high electron mobilities , and excellent chemical , thermal , and photochemical stabilities. 4 These materials are electron deficient due to the substitution of an aromatic core with one or two sets of π-accepting imide groups that are mutually conjugated. The widely used rylene diimides include perylene diimides ( PDIs , 1 ) and naphthalene diimides ( NDIs , 2 ) ( Figure 1 ). Zhan and co-workers reported the synthesis of the first soluble rylene-based fully conjugated polymer. 5 Top-gate OFETs based on this PDI- dithienothiophene copolymer exhibited a saturation electron mobility ( μ e ) of 6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 , current on / off ratio ( I on / I off ) of 10^4 , and a low threshold voltage ( V th ) of 7 V in air. 6 Moreover , all - polymer solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors exhibited power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as high as 1.5% ( AM1.5 , 100 mW cm^-2 ). 7-9 Facchetti et al. reported a conjugated copolymer of NDI and bithiophene ; 10 OFET devices based on this polymer fabricated in a top-gate , bottom - contact configuration with polymeric dielectrics exhibited μ e of 0.1-0.85 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 under ambient conditions with I on / I off > 10^5 . 11 The simplest aromatic imide system is phthalimide ( 3 ) and thiophene imide ( 4 ) ( Figure 1 ). A few literatures reported phthalimide - containing conjugated polymers such as poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s , 12 a polyaniline derivative , 13 and a polythiophene derivative.

Let's think step by step.

1. Conjugated polymers:
 * p-type: poly(phenylene ethynylene)s, polyaniline derivative, polythiophene derivative
 * n-type: rylene diimides (e.g. perylene diimides, naphthalene diimides), phthalimide, thiophene imide
2. Organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs):
 * p-type: poly(phenylene ethynylene)s, polyaniline derivative, polythiophene derivative
 * n-type: rylene diimides (e.g. perylene diimides, naphthalene diimides), phthalimide, thiophene imide
3. Organic photovoltaic cells (OPVs):
 * p-type: poly(phenylene ethynylene)s, polyaniline derivative, polythiophene derivative
 * n-type: rylene diimides (e.g. perylene diimides, naphthalene diimides), phthalimide, thiophene imide
4. Organic field-effect transistors (OFETs):
 * p-type: poly(phenylene ethynylene)s, polyaniline derivative, polythiophene derivative
 * n-type: rylene diimides (e.g. perylene diimides, naphthalene diimides), phthalimide, thiophene imide
5. Other materials:
 * aromatic imides (e.g. rylene diimides, phthalimide, thiophene imide)
 * polythiophene derivative

Note: Some of these materials can be classified as both p-type and n-type depending on their electronic properties and the specific application.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

Sure, here are the relevant entities from the text that refer to the property name of a material:

1. "p-type"
2. "n-type"
3. "polythiophene derivative"

These are the only entities in the text that refer directly to the property name of a material. The other entities mentioned in the text (e.g. "rylene diimides", "naphthalene diimides", "phthalimide", "thiophene imide") are not property names of materials, but rather specific types of materials that can be used to create p-type or n-type materials.

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Certainly! Here are the valid entities from the paragraph that refer to the property name of a material, presented in a Markdown table with one column titled "Property Name":

| Property Name |
| --- |
| p-type |
| n-type |
| polythiophene derivative |

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions.

PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: Significant progress has been made in synthesis of conjugated polymers and their applications for optoelectronic device such as organic light - emitting diodes ( OLEDs ) , organic photovoltaic cells ( OPVs ) , and organic field - effect transistors ( OFETs ) since Heeger , MacDiarmid , and Shirakawa discovered conducting polymers in 1976.^1 As a result of the low - cost , light - weight , and flexibility advantages , optoelectronic devices based on conjugated polymers are a promising cost - effective alternative to inorganic materials - based microelectronics. Conjugated polymers can be classified as hole ( p - type ) or electron ( n - type ) transporting materials according to the type of orderly transferring charge carriers. Most of conjugated polymers are p - type semiconductors that have seen a dramatic rise in performance over the past decade while much less attention has been devoted to n - type semiconducting polymers that have lagged behind their p - type counterparts. 2 Organic n - type materials are essential for the fabrication of organic p-n junctions , OPVs , n-channel OFETs , OLEDs , and complementary logic circuits. 3 The n - type building blocks are the core components in n - type semiconducting polymers. Aromatic imides such as rylene diimides are one of the classical n - type building blocks and can exhibit relatively high electron affinities , high electron mobilities , and excellent chemical , thermal , and photochemical stabilities. 4 These materials are electron deficient due to the substitution of an aromatic core with one or two sets of π-accepting imide groups that are mutually conjugated. The widely used rylene diimides include perylene diimides ( PDIs , 1 ) and naphthalene diimides ( NDIs , 2 ) ( Figure 1 ). Zhan and co-workers reported the synthesis of the first soluble rylene-based fully conjugated polymer. 5 Top-gate OFETs based on this PDI- dithienothiophene copolymer exhibited a saturation electron mobility ( μ e ) of 6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 , current on / off ratio ( I on / I off ) of 10^4 , and a low threshold voltage ( V th ) of 7 V in air. 6 Moreover , all - polymer solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors exhibited power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as high as 1.5% ( AM1.5 , 100 mW cm^-2 ). 7-9 Facchetti et al. reported a conjugated copolymer of NDI and bithiophene ; 10 OFET devices based on this polymer fabricated in a top-gate , bottom - contact configuration with polymeric dielectrics exhibited μ e of 0.1-0.85 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 under ambient conditions with I on / I off > 10^5 . 11 The simplest aromatic imide system is phthalimide ( 3 ) and thiophene imide ( 4 ) ( Figure 1 ). A few literatures reported phthalimide - containing conjugated polymers such as poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s , 12 a polyaniline derivative , 13 and a polythiophene derivative.

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Let's identify the values of material properties in the paragraph:

1. Values of material properties for conjugated polymers:
 * Hole (p-type) transporting materials:
  + Electron affinity: Not mentioned
  + Electron mobility: Not mentioned
  + Chemical stability: Not mentioned
 * Electron (n-type) transporting materials:
  + Electron affinity: Not mentioned
  + Electron mobility: Not mentioned
  + Chemical stability: Not mentioned
2. Values of material properties for specific conjugated polymers:
 * Perylene diimides (PDIs):
  + Electron affinity: Not mentioned
  + Electron mobility: 6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 (ref. 5)
  + Chemical stability: Not mentioned
 * Naphthalene diimides (NDIs):
  + Electron affinity: Not mentioned
  + Electron mobility: Not mentioned
  + Chemical stability: Not mentioned
 * Phthalimide (3):
  + Electron affinity: Not mentioned
  + Electron mobility: Not mentioned
  + Chemical stability: Not mentioned
 * Thiophene imide (4):
  + Electron affinity: Not mentioned
  + Electron mobility: Not mentioned
  + Chemical stability: Not mentioned
3. Values of material properties for specific devices based on conjugated polymers:
 * Top-gate OFETs based on PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer:
  + Electron mobility: 6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 (ref. 5)
  + Current on/off ratio: Not mentioned
  + Threshold voltage: 7 V (ref. 5)
 * All-polymer solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors:
  + Power conversion efficiency: Up to 1.5% (AM1.5, 100 mW cm^-2) (ref. 7-9)
 * Conjugated copolymer of NDI and bithiophene:
  + Electron mobility: Not mentioned (ref. 10)
  + Current on/off ratio: Not mentioned (ref. 10)
  + Threshold voltage: Not mentioned (ref. 10)

Note: The values mentioned in the references are based on the specific polymers or devices described in each reference, and may not be directly applicable to all conjugated polymers or devices.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

Sure, here are the relevant entities that refer to the value of material properties in the given text:

1. "6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1" - This refers to the electron mobility value of the PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer.
2. "7 V" - This refers to the threshold voltage value of the PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer.
3. "1.5%" - This refers to the power conversion efficiency value of the all-polymer solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions.
